castItem.roleDesc: an ambassador from Antony to Cæsar.
sister to Cæsar and wife to Antony.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: Alexandria. A room in Cleopatra's palace.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
Nay, but this dotage of our general's
O'erflows the measure: those his goodly eyes,
That o'er the files and musters of the war
Have glow'd like plated Mars,
now bend, now turn,
The office and devotion of their view
Upon a tawny front: his captain's heart,
Which in the scuffles of great fights hath burst
The buckles on his breast, reneges all temper,
And is become the bellows and the fan
To cool a gipsy's lust.
Flourish. Enter ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, her Ladies, the
Train, with Eunuchs fanning her.
Look, where they come:
Take but good note, and you shall see in him.
The triple pillar of the world transform'd
Into a strumpet's fool: behold and see.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: If it be love indeed, tell me how much.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There's beggary in the love that can be reckon'd.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: I'll set a bourn how far to be beloved.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Then must thou needs find out new heaven,
new earth.
Enter an Attendant.

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p: News, my good lord, from Rome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Grates me: the sum.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
Ant.
sp.p: How, my love !

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Perchance! nay, and most like:
You must not stay here longer, your dismission
Is come from Cæsar; therefore hear it, Antony.
Where's Fulvia's process ? Cæsar's I would say ? both ?
Call in the messengers. As I am Egypt's queen,
Thou blushest, Antony; and that blood of thine
Is Cæsar's homager: else so thy cheek pays shame
When shrill-tongued Fulvia scolds. The messengers

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Let Rome in Tiber melt, and the wide arch
Of the ranged empire fall! Here is my space.
Kingdoms are clay: our dungy earth alike
Feeds beast as man: the nobleness of life
Is to do thus; when such a mutual pair Embracing.
And such a twain can do't, in which I bind,
On pain of punishment, the world to weet
We stand up peerless.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Excellent falsehood!
Why did he marry Fulvia, and not love her ?
I'll seem the fool I am not; Antony
Will be himself.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
But stirr'd by Cleopatra.
Now, for the love of Love and her soft hours,
Let's not confound the time with conference harsh:
There's not a minute of our lives should stretch
Without some pleasure now. What sport tonight ?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Hear the ambassadors.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Fie, wrangling queen!
Whom every thing becomes, to chide, to laugh,
To weep; whose every passion fully strives
To make itself, in thee, fair and admired!
No messenger, but thine; and all alone
To-night we'll wander through the streets and note
The qualities of people. Come, my queen;
Last night you did desire it: speak not to us.
Exeunt Ant. and Cleo. with their train.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Is Cæsar with Antonius prized so slight ?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
Sir, sometimes, when he is not Antony,
He comes too short of that great property
Which still should go with Antony.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
I am full sorry
That he approves the common
liar, who
Thus speaks of him at Rome: but I will hope
Of better deeds to-morrow. Rest you happy! Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE II
div2.stage: Enter CHARMIAN, IRAS, ALEXAS, and a Soothsayer.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most
any thing Alexas,
almost most absolute Alexas,
where's the soothsayer
that you praised so to
the queen? O, that I knew this
husband,
which, you say, must charge his horns with
garlands !

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Soothsayer!

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: Your will?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Is this the man ? Is't you, sir, that know things ?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
In nature's infinite book of secrecy
A little I
can read.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Show him your hand. Enter ENOBARBUS.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Bring in the banquet quickly; wine enough
Cleopatra's health to drink.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Good sir, give me good fortune.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: I make not, but foresee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Pray, then, foresee me one.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: You shall be yet far fairer than you are.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He means in flesh.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: No, you shall paint when you are old.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Wrinkles forbid!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Vex not his prescience; be attentive.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Hush !

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: You shall be more beloving than beloved.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I had rather heat my liver with drinking.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Nay, hear him.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Good now, some excellent fortune!
Let me
be married to three kings in a forenoon,
and widow
them all: let me have a
child at fifty, to whom Herod
of Jewry may
do homage: find me to marry me with
Octavius
Cæsar, and companion me with my mistress.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: You shall outlive the lady whom you serve.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: O excellent! I love long life better than figs.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
You have seen and proved a fairer former fortune
Than that which is to approach.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Then belike my children shall have
no names:
prithee, how many boys and
wenches must I have ?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
If every of your wishes had a womb,
And fertile
every wish, a million.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Out, fool! I forgive thee for a witch.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
You think none but your sheets are privy to
your wishes.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Nay, come, tell Iras hers.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: We'll know all our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Mine, and most of our fortunes, to night,
shall
be—drunk to bed.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: There's a palm presages chastity, if nothing else.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
E'en as the o'erflowing Nilus pre sageth
famine.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p:
Go, you wild bedfellow, you cannot
soothsay.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Nay, if an oily palm be not a fruitful
prognostication,
I cannot scratch mine ear.
Prithee, tell her
but a worky-day fortune.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: Your fortunes are alike.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: But how, but how ? give me particulars.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: I have said.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p:
Am I not an inch of fortune better
than she ?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Well, if you were but an inch of fortune
better
than I, where would you choose it?

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: Not in my husband's nose.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Our worser thoughts heavens mend!
Alexas,—come, his fortune, his fortune! O,
let him
marry a woman that cannot go, sweet
Isis, I beseech thee!
and let her die too, and
give him a worse! and let worst
follow worse,
till the worst of all follow him laughing to
his
grave, fifty-fold a cuckold! Good Isis, hear
me this
prayer, though thou deny me a matter
of more weight;
good Isis, I beseech thee!

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p:
Amen. Dear goddess, hear that
prayer of the
people! for, as it is a heartbreaking
to see a handsome
man loose-wived,
so it is a deadly sorrow to behold a
foul knave
uncuckolded: therefore, dear Isis, keep decorum,
and fortune him accordingly !

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Lo, now, if it lay in their hands to
make me a
cuckold, they would make themselves
whores, but
they'ld do't!

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Hush! here comes Antony.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Not he; the queen. Enter CLEOPATRA.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Saw you my lord ?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: No, lady.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Was he not here ?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No, madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
He was disposed to mirth; but on the sudden
A Roman thought hath struck him.
Enobarbus!

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Madam ?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Seek him, and bring him hither. Where's Alexas ?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Here, at your service.
My lord approaches.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
We will not look upon him:
go with us. Exeunt. Enter ANTONY with a Messenger and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Fulvia thy wife
first came into the field.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Against my brother Lucius ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Ay:
But soon that war had end,
and the time's state
Made friends of them, joining their force 'gainst Cæsar;
Whose better issue in the war, from Italy,
Upon the first encounter, drave them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, what worst ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: The nature of bad news infects the teller.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
When it concerns the fool or coward. On:
Things that are past are done with me. 'Tis thus:
Who tells me true, though in his tale lie death,
I hear him as he flatter'd.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Labienus—

This is stiff news-
hath, with his Parthian force,


Extended Asia from Euphrates;

His conquering 
banner shook from Syria

To Lydia 
and to Ionia;

Whilst—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Antony, thou wouldst say,—

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: O, my lord !

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Speak to me home,
mince not the general tongue:
Name
Cleopatra as she is call'd in Rome;
Rail thou in Fulvia's phrase; and taunt my faults
With such full license as both truth and malice
Have power to utter. O, then we bring forth weeds,
When our quick minds lie still; and our ills told us
Is as our earing. Fare thee well awhile.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: At your noble pleasure. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: From Sicyon, ho, the news! Speak there !

sp.speaker: First Att.
sp.p:
The man from Sicyon,—
is there such an one ?

sp.speaker: Sec. Att.
sp.p: He stays upon your will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Let him appear.
These strong Egyptian fetters I must break,
Or lose myself in dotage.
Enter another Messenger.
What are you ?

sp.speaker: Sec. Mess.
sp.p: Fulvia thy wife is dead.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where died she ?

sp.speaker: Sec. Mess.
sp.p:
In Sicyon:
Her length of sickness,
with what else more serious
Importeth thee to know, this bears. Gives a letter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Forbear me. Exit Sec. Messenger.
There's a great spirit gone! Thus did I desire it:
What our contempt doth often hurl from us,
We wish it ours again; the present pleasure,
By revolution lowering, does become
The opposite of itself: she's good, being gone;
The hand could pluck her back that shoved her on.
I must from this enchanting queen break off:
Ten thousand harms, more than the ills I know,
My idleness doth hatch.
How now! Enobarbus! Re-enter ENOBARBUS.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: What's your pleasure, sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I must with haste from hence.

sp.speaker: Eno.
Ant.
sp.p: I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Under a compelling occasion, let
women die;
it were pity to cast them away
for nothing; though, between
them and a great
cause, they should be esteemed
nothing. Cleo patra,
catching but the least noise of this,
dies
instantly; I have seen her die twenty times
upon
far poorer moment: I do think there
is mettle in death,
which commits some loving
act upon her, she hath such
a celerity in dying.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: She is cunning past man's thought.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Alack, sir, no; her passions are made
of nothing
but the finest part of pure love: we
cannot call her winds
and waters sighs and
tears; they are greater storms
and tempests
than almanacs can report: this cannot
be cunning
in her; if it be, she makes a shower of
rain
as well as Jove.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Would I had never seen her.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
O, sir, you had then left unseen a
wonderful
piece of work; which not to have
been blest withal
would have discredited your travel.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fulvia is dead.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Sir ?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fulvia is dead.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Fulvia!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dead.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Why, sir, give the gods a thankful
sacrifice.
When it pleaseth their deities to take
the wife of a man
from him, it shows to man
the tailors of the earth; comforting
therein,
that when old robes are worn out,
there are
members to make new. If there were no more
women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut,
and the
case to be lamented: this grief is
crowned with consolation;
your old smock
brings forth a new petticoat:
and indeed the
tears live in an onion that should water
this sorrow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
The business she hath broached in the state
Cannot endure my absence.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
And the business you have broached
here cannot
be without you; especially that
of Cleopatra's, which
wholly depends on your abode.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
No more light answers.
Let our officers
Have notice what we purpose. I shall break
The cause of our expedience to the queen,
And get her leave to part. For not alone
The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches,
Do strongly speak to us; but the letters too
Of many our contriving friends in Rome
Petition us at home: Sextus Pompeius
Hath given the dare to Cæsar, and commands
The empire of the sea: our slippery people,
Whose love is never link'd to the deserver
Till his deserts are past, begin to throw
Pompey the Great and all his dignities
Upon his son; who, high in name and power,
Higher than both in blood and life, stands up
For the main soldier: whose quality, going on,
The sides o' the world may danger: much is breeding,
Which, like the courser's hair, hath yet but life,
And not a serpent's poison. Say, our pleasure,
To such whose place is under us, requires
Our quick remove from hence.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: I shall do't. Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE III
div2.stage: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Where is he ?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I did not see him since.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
See where he is,
who's with him, what he does:
I did not send you: if you find him sad,
Say I am dancing; if in mirth, report
That I am sudden sick: quick, and return. Exit Alexas.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Madam, methinks, if you did love him dearly,
You do not hold the method to enforce
The like from him.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: What should I do, I do not ?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: In each thing give him way, cross him in nothing.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Thou teachest like a fool; the way to lose him.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Tempt him not so too far; I wish, forbear:
In time we hate that which we often fear.
But here comes Antony. Enter ANTONY.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: I am sick and sullen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose,

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Help me away, dear Charmian; I shall fall:
It cannot be thus long, the sides of nature
Will not sustain it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now, my dearest queen,—

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Pray you, stand further from me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
I know by that same eye, there's some good news.
What says the married woman ? You may go:
Would she had never given you leave to come!
Let her not say 'tis I that keep you here:
I have no power upon you; hers you are.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The gods best know,—

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
O, never was there queen
So mightily betray'd! yet at the first
I saw the treasons planted.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Cleopatra,—

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Why should I think you can be mine and true,
Though you in swearing shake the throned gods,
Who have been false to Fulvia ?
Riotous madness,
To be entangled with those mouth-made vows,
Which break themselves in swearing!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Most sweet queen,—

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Nay, pray you, seek no color for your going,
But bid farewell, and go:
when you sued staying,
Then was the time for words: no going then;
Eternity was in our lips and eyes,
Bliss in our brows' bent; none our parts so poor,
But was a race of heaven: they are so still,
Or thou, the greatest soldier of the world,
Art turn'd the greatest liar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How now, lady

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
I would I had thy inches; thou shouldst know
There were a heart in Egypt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Hear me, queen:
The strong necessity of time commands
Our services awhile; but my full heart
Remains in use with you. Our Italy
Shines o'er with civil swords: Sextus Pompeius
Makes his approaches to the port of Rome:
Equality of two domestic powers
Breed scrupulous faction: the hated, grown to strength,
Are newly grown to love: the condemn'd Pompey,
Rich in his father's honor, creeps apace,
Into the hearts of such as have not thrived
Upon the present state, whose numbers threaten;
And quietness, grown sick of rest, would purge
By any desperate change: my more particular,
And that which most with you should safe my going,
Is Fulvia's death.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Though age from folly could not give me freedom,
It does from childishness: can Fulvia die ?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
She's dead, my queen:
Look here, and at thy sovereign leisure read
The garboils she awaked; at the last, best:
See when and where she died.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
O most false love!
Where be the sacred vials thou shouldst fill
With sorrowful water ? Now I see, I see,
In Fulvia's death, how mine received shall be.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Quarrel no more, but be prepared to know
The purposes I bear; which are, or cease,
As you shall give the advice. By the fire
That quickens Nilus' slime, I go from hence
Thy soldier, servant; making peace or war
As thou affect'st.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
Ant.
Cleo.
sp.p:
So Fulvia told me.
I prithee, turn aside and weep for her,
Then bid adieu to me, and say the tears
Belong to Egypt: good now, play one scene
Of excellent dissembling; and let it look
Life perfect honor.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You'll heat my blood: no more.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: You can do better yet; but this is meetly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now, by my sword,—

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
And target. Still he mends;
But this is not the best. Look, prithee, Charmian,
How this Herculean Roman does become
The carriage of his chafe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'll leave you, lady.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Courteous lord, one word.
Sir, you and I must part, but that's not it:
Sir, you and I have loved, but there's not it;
That you know well: something it is I would,
O, my oblivion is a very Antony,
And I am all forgotten.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
But that your royalty
Holds idleness your subject, I should take you
For idleness itself.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
'Tis sweating labor
To bear such idleness so near the heart
As Cleopatra this. But, sir, forgive me;
Since my becomings kill me, when they do not
Eye well to you: your honor calls you hence;
Therefore be deaf to my unpitied folly.
And all the gods go with you! upon your sword
Sit laurel victory ! and smooth success
Be strew'd before your feet!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Let us go. Come;
Our separation so abides, and flies,
That thou, residing here, go'st yet with me,
And I, hence fleeting, here remain with thee.
Away! Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE IV
div2.stage:
Enter OCTAVIUS CÆSAR, reading a letter, LEPIDUS,
and their Train.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
You may see, Lepidus, and henceforth know,
It is not Cæsar's natural vice to hate
Our great competitor: from Alexandria
This is the news: he fishes, drinks, and wastes
The lamps of night in revel; is not more manlike
Than Cleopatra; nor the queen of Ptolemy
More womanly than he; hardly gave audience, or
Vouchsafed to think he had partners: you shall find there
A man who is the abstract of all faults
That all men follow.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
I must not think
there are
Evils enow to darken all his goodness:
His faults in him seem as the spots of heaven,
More fiery by night's blackness; hereditary,
Rather than purchased; what he cannot change,
Than what he chooses.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
You are too indulgent. Let us grant, it is not
Amiss to tumble on the bed of Ptolemy;
To give a kingdom for a mirth; to sit
And keep the turn of tippling with a slave;
To reel the streets at noon, and stand the buffet
With knaves that smell of sweat: say this becomes him,—
As his composure must be rare indeed
Whom these things cannot blemish,—yet must Antony
No way excuse his soils, when we do bear
So great weight in his lightness. If he fill'd
His vacancy with his voluptuousness,
Full surfeits, and the dryness of his bones,
Call on him for't: but to confound such time,
That drums him from his sport, and speaks as loud
As his own state and ours,—'tis to be chid
As we rate boys, who, being mature in knowledge,
Pawn their experience to their present pleasure,
And so rebel to judgment.
Enter a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: Here's more news.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Thy biddings have been done; and every hour,
Most noble Cæsar, shalt thou have report
How 'tis abroad. Pompey is strong at sea;
And it appears he is beloved of those
That only have fear'd Cæsar: to the ports
The discontents repair, and men's reports
Give him much wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
I should have known no less.
It hath been taught us from the primal state,
That he which is was wish'd until he were;
And the ebb'd man,
ne'er loved till ne'er worth love,
Comes dear'd by being lack'd. This common body,
Like to a vagabond flag upon the stream,
Goes to and back, lackeying the varying tide,
To rot itself with motion.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Cæsar, I bring thee word,
Menecrates and Menas, famous pirates,
Make the sea serve them, which they ear and wound
With keels of every kind: many hot inroads
They make in Italy; the borders maritime
Lack blood to think on 't, and flush youth revolt:
No vessel can peep forth, but 'tis as soon
Taken as seen; for Pompey's name strikes more
Than could his war resisted.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Antony,
Leave thy lascivious wassails. When thou once
Wast beaten from Modena, where thou slew'st
Hirtius and Pansa, consuls, at thy heel
Did famine follow; whom thou fought'st against,
Though daintily brought up, with patience more
Than savages could suffer: thou didst drink
The stale of horses, and the gilded puddle
Which beasts would cough at: thy palate then did deign
The roughest berry on the rudest hedge;
Yea, like the stag, when snow the pasture sheets,
The barks of trees thou browsed'st; on the Alps
It is reported thou didst eat strange flesh,
Which some did die to look on: and all this-
It wounds thine honor that I speak it now—
Was borne so like a soldier, that thy cheek
So much as lank'd not.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: 'Tis pity of him.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Let his shames quickly
Drive him to Rome: 'tis time we twain
Did show ourselves i' the field; and to that end
Assemble we immediate council: Pompey
Thrives in our idleness.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
To-morrow, Cæsar,
I shall be furnish'd to inform you rightly
Both what by sea and land I can be able
To front this present time.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Till which encounter,
It is my business too. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Farewell, my lord: what you shall know meantime
Of stirs abroad, I shall beseech you, sir,
To let me be partaker.

sp.speaker: Cæs.

div2.head: SCENE V
div2.stage: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Charmian!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Madam ?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Ha, ha!
Give me to drink mandragora.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Why, madam ?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
That I might sleep out this great gap of time
My Antony is away.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: You think of him too much.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: O, 'tis treason !

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Madam, I trust, not so.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Thou, eunuch Mardian!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's your highness' pleasure ?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Not now to hear thee sing; I take no pleasure
In aught an eunuch has: 'tis well for thee,
That, being unseminar'd, thy freer thoughts
May not fly forth of Egypt. Hast thou affections ?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, gracious madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Indeed !

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Not in deed, madam; for I can do nothing
But what indeed is honest to be done:
Yet have I fierce affections, and think
What Venus did with Mars.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
O Charmian,
Where think'st thou he is now ? Stands he, or sits he ?
Or does he walk ? or is he on his horse ?
O happy horse, to bear the weight of Antony !
Do bravely, horse ! for wot'st thou whom thou movest ?
The demi-Atlas of this earth, the arm
And burgonet of men. He's speaking now,
Or murmuring 'Where's my serpent of old Nile ?'
For so he calls me: now I feed myself
With most delicious poison. Think on me,
That am with Phoebus' amorous pinches black,
And wrinkled deep in time ? Broad-fronted Cæsar,
When thou wast here above the ground, I was
A morsel for a monarch: and great Pompey
Would stand and make his eyes grow in my brow;
There would he anchor his aspect and die
With looking on his life.
Enter ALEXAS, from CÆSAR.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sovereign of Egypt, hail !

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
How much unlike art thou Mark Antony !
Yet, coming from him, that great medicine hath
With his tinct gilded thee.
How goes it with my brave Mark Antony ?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Last thing he did, dear queen,
He kiss'd,—the last of many doubled kisses,—
This orient pearl. His speech sticks in my heart.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Mine ear must pluck it thence.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
'Good friend,' quoth he,
'Say, the firm Roman to great Egypt sends
This treasure of an oyster; at whose foot,
To mend the petty present, I will piece
Her opulent throne with kingdoms; all the east,
Say thou, shall call her mistress.' So he nodded,
And soberly did mount an arm-gaunt steed,
Who neigh'd so high, that what I would have spoke
Was beastly dumb'd by him.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: What, was he sad or merry ?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Like to the time o' the year between the extremes
Of hot and cold, he was nor sad nor merry.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
O well-divided disposition! Note him,
Note him, good Charmian, 'tis the man; but note him:
He was not sad, for he would shine on those
That make their looks by his; he was not merry,
Which seem'd to tell them his remembrance lay
In Egypt with his joy; but between both:
O heavenly mingle! Be'st thou sad or merry,
The violence of either thee becomes,
So does it no man else. Met'st thou my posts ?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Ay, madam, twenty several messengers:
Why do you send so thick ?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Who's born that day
When I forget to send
to Antony,
Shall die a beggar. Ink and paper, Charmian.
Welcome, my good Alexas. Did I, Charmian,
Ever
love Cæsar so ?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: O that brave Cæsar !

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Be choked with such another emphasis !
Say, the brave Antony.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: The valiant Cæsar !

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
By Isis, I will give thee bloody teeth,
If thou with Cæsar paragon again
My man of men.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
By your most gracious pardon,
I sing but after you.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
My salad days,
When I was green in judgment: cold in blood,
To say as I said then! But, come, away;
Get me ink and paper:
He shall have every day a several greeting,
Or I'll unpeople
Egypt. Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage:
Enter POMPEY, MENECRATES, and MENAS, in
warlike manner.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
If the great gods be just, they shall assist
The deeds of justest men.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.p:
Know, worthy Pompey,
That what they do delay,
they not deny.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Whiles we are suitors to their throne, decays
The thing we sue for.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.p:
We, ignorant of ourselves,
Beg often our own harms, which the wise powers
Deny us for our good; so find we profit
By losing of our prayers.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
I shall do well:
The people love me, and the sea is mine;
My powers are crescent, and my auguring hope
Says it will come to the full. Mark Antony
In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make
No wars without doors: Cæsar gets money where
He loses hearts: Lepidus flatters both,
Of both is flatter'd; but he neither loves,
Nor either cares for him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Cæsar and Lepidus
Are in the field: a mighty strength they carry.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Where have you this ? 'tis false.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: From Silvius, sir.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
He dreams: I know they are in Rome together,
Looking for Antony. But all the charms of love,
Salt Cleopatra, soften thy waned lip!
Let witchcraft join with beauty, lust with both !
Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts,
Keep his brain fuming; Epicurean cooks
Sharpen with cloyless sauce his appetite;
That sleep and feeding may prorogue his honor
Even till a Lethe'd dulness!
Enter VARRIUS.
How now, Varrius!

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p:
This is most certain that I shall deliver:
Mark Antony is every hour in Rome
Expected: since he went from Egypt 'tis
A space for further travel.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
I could have given less matter
A better ear. Menas, I did not think
This amorous surfeiter would have donn'd his helm
For such a petty war: his soldiership
Is twice the other twain: but let us rear
The higher our opinion, that our stirring
Can from the lap of Egypt's widow pluck
The ne'er-lust-wearied Antony.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
I cannot hope
Cæsar and Antony shall well greet together:
His wife that's dead did trespasses to Cæsar;
His brother warr'd upon him; although, I think,
Not moved by Antony.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
I know not, Menas,
How lesser enmities may give way to greater.
Were't not that we stand up against them all,
'Twere pregnant they should square between themselves;
For they have entertained cause enough
To draw their swords: but how the fear of us
May cement their divisions and bind up
The petty difference, we yet not know.
Be't as our gods will have't! It only stands
Our lives upon to use our strongest hands.
Come, Menas. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Good Enobarbus, 'tis a worthy deed,
And shall become you well, to entreat your captain
To soft and gentle speech.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
I shall entreat him
To answer like himself: if Cæsar move him,
Let Antony look over Cæsar's head
And speak as loud as Mars. By Jupiter,
Were I the wearer of Antonius' beard,
I would not shave't to-day.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
'Tis not a time
For private stomaching.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Every time
Serves for the matter that is then
born in't.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: But small to greater matters must give way.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Not if the small come first.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Your speech is passion:
But, pray you, stir
no embers up. Here comes
The noble Antony.
Enter ANTONY and VENTIDUS.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
And yonder, Cæsar.
Enter CÆSAR, MECÆNAS, and AGRIPPA.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
If we compose well here, to Parthia:
Hark, Ventidius.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
I do not know,
Mecænas; ask Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Noble friends,
That which combined us was most great, and let not
A leaner action rend us. What's amiss,
May it be gently heard: when we debate
Our trivial difference loud, we do commit
Murder in healing wounds: then, noble partners,
The rather, for I earnestly beseech,
Touch you the sourest points with sweetest terms,
Nor curstness grow to the matter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
'Tis spoken well.
Were we before our armies, and to fight.
I should do thus. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: Welcome to Rome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: Sit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sit, sir.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: Nay, then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I learn, you take things ill which are not so,
Or being, concern you not.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
I must be laugh'd at,
If, or for nothing or a little, I
Should say myself offended, and with you
Chiefly i' the world; more laugh'd at, that I should
Once name you derogately, when to sound your name
It not concern'd me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
My being in Egypt, Cæsar,
What was't to you ?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
No more than my residing here at Rome
Might be to you in Egypt: yet, if you there
Did practise on my state, your being in Egypt
Might be my question.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How intend you, practised ?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
You may be pleased to catch at mine intent
By what did here befal me. Your wife and brother
Made wars upon me; and their contestation
Was theme for you, you were the word of war.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
You do mistake your business; my brother never
Did urge me in his act: I did inquire it;
And have my learning from some true reports,
That drew their swords with you. Did he not rather
Discredit my authority with yours;
And make the wars alike against my stomach,
Having alike your cause ? Of this my letters
Before did satisfy you. If you'll patch a quarrel,
As matter whole you have not to make it with,
It must not be with this.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
You praise yourself
By laying defects of judgment
to me; but
You patch'd up your excuses.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Not so, not so;
I know you could not lack, I am certain on't,
Very necessity of this thought, that I,
Your partner in the cause 'gainst which he fought,
Could not with graceful eyes attend those wars
Which fronted mine own peace. As for my wife,
I would you had her spirit in such another:
The third o' the world is yours; which with a snaffle
You may pace easy, but not such a wife.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Would we had all such wives, that
the men
might go to wars with the women!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
So much uncurbable, her garboils, Cæsar,
Made out of her impatience, which not wanted
Shrewdness of policy too, I grieving grant
Did you too much disquiet: for that you must
But say, I could not help it.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
I wrote to you
When rioting in Alexandria; you
Did pocket up my letters, and with taunts
Did gibe my missive out of audience.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Sir,
He fell upon me ere admitted: then
Three kings I had newly feasted, and did want
Of what I was i' the morning: but next day
I told him of myself; which was as much
As to have ask'd him pardon. Let this fellow
Be nothing of our strife; if we contend,
Out of our question wipe him.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
You have broken
The article of your oath;
which you shall never
Have tongue to charge me with.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: Soft, Cæsar !

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
No,
Lepidus, let him speak:
The honor is sacred which he talks on now,
Supposing that I lack'd it. But, on, Cæsar;
The article of my oath.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
Ant.
sp.p:
Neglected, rather;
And then when poison'd hours had bound me up
>From mine own knowledge. As nearly as I may,
I'll play the penitent to you: but mine honesty
Shall not make poor my greatness, nor my power
Work without it. Truth is, that Fulvia,
To have me out of Egypt, made wars here;
For which myself, the ignorant motive, do
So far ask pardon as befits mine honor
To stoop in such a case.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: 'Tis noble spoken.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p:
If it might please you, to enforce no further
The griefs between ye: to forget them quite
Were to remember that the present need
Speaks to atone you.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: Worthily spoken, Mecænas.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Or, if you borrow one another's love
for the
instant, you may, when you hear no
more words of
Pompey, return it again: you
shall have time to wrangle
in when you have
nothing else to do.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou art a soldier only: speak no more.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
That truth should be silent I had almost
forgot.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
You wrong this presence; therefore speak no
more.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Go to, then; your considerate stone.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
I do not much dislike the matter, but
The manner of his speech; for't cannot be
We shall remain in friendship, our conditions
So differing in their acts. Yet, if I knew
What hoop should hold us stanch, from edge to edge
O' the world I would pursue it.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: Give me leave, Cæsar,—

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: Speak, Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p:
Thou hast a sister by the mother's side,
Admired
Octavia: great Mark Antony
Is now a widower.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Say not so, Agrippa:
If Cleopatra heard you, your reproof
Were well deserved of rashness.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I am not married, Cæsar: let me hear
Agrippa
further speak.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p:
To hold you in perpetual amity,
To make you brothers, and to knit your hearts
With an unslipping knot, take Antony
Octavia to his wife; whose beauty claims
No worse a husband than the best of men;
Whose virtue and whose general graces speak
That which none else can utter. By this marriage,
All little jealousies, which now seem great,
And all great fears, which now import their dangers,
Would then be nothing: truths would be tales,
Where now half tales be truths: her love to both
Would, each to other and all loves to both,
Draw after her. Pardon what I have spoke;
For 'tis a studied, not a present thought,
By duty ruminated.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Will Cæsar speak?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Not till he hears how Antony is touch'd
With what is spoke already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
What power is in Agrippa,
If I would say, 'Agrippa, be it so,'
To make this good ?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
The power of Cæsar,
and
His power unto Octavia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
May I never
To this good purpose, that so fairly shows,
Dream of impediment ! Let me have thy hand :
Further this act of grace: and from this hour
The heart of brothers govern in our loves
And sway our great designs!

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
There is my hand.
A sister I bequeath you, whom no brother
Did ever love so dearly: let her live
To join our kingdoms and our hearts; and never
Fly off our loves again!

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: Happily, amen!

sp.speaker: Ant.
Lep.
sp.p:
Time calls upon's:
Of us must Pompey presently be sought,
Or else he seeks out us.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where lies he?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: About the mount Misenum.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is his strength by land?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Great and increasing: but by sea
He is an absolute master.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
So is the fame.
Would we had spoke together! Haste we for it:
Yet, ere we put ourselves in arms, dispatch we
The business we have talk'd of.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
With most gladness:
And do invite you to my sister's view,
Whither straight I'll lead you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Let us, Lepidus,
Not lack your company.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Noble Antony,
Not sickness should detain
me.
Flourish. Exeunt Cæsar, Antony, and Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p: Welcome from Egypt, sir.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Half the heart of Cæsar, worthy
Mecænas! My
honorable friend, Agrippa !

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: Good Enobarbus!

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p:
We have cause to be glad that matters
are so
well digested. You stayed well by 't
in Egypt.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Ay, sir; we did sleep day out of
countenance,
and made the night light with
drinking.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p:
Eight wild-boars roasted whole at a
breakfast,
and but twelve persons there; is
this true ?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
This was but as a fly by an eagle:
we had much
more monstrous matter of feast,
which worthily deserved
noting.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p:
She's a most triumphant lady, if report be
square to her.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
When she first met Mark Antony, she
pursed
up his heart, upon the river of Cydnus.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p:
There she appeared indeed; or my
reporter devised
well for her.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
I will tell you.
The barge she sat in, like a burnish'd throne,
Burn'd on the water: the poop was beaten gold;
Purple the sails, and so perfumed that
The winds were love-sick
with them; the oars were silver,
Which to the tune of flutes kept stroke, and made
The water which they beat to follow faster,
As amorous of their strokes. For her own person,
It beggar'd all description: she did lie
In her pavilion—cloth-of-gold of tissue—
O'er-picturing that Venus where we see
The fancy outwork nature: on each side her
Stood pretty dimpled boys, like smiling Cupids,
With divers-color'd fans, whose wind did seem
To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool,
And what they undid did.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: O, rare for Antony!

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Her gentlewomen, like the Nereides,
So many mermaids, tended her i' the eyes,
And made their bends adornings: at the helm
A seeming mermaid steers: the silken tackle
Swell with the touches of those flower-soft hands,
That yarely frame the office. From the barge
A strange invisible perfume hits the sense
Of the adjacent wharfs. The city cast
Her people out upon her; and Antony,
Enthroned i' the market-place, did sit alone,
Whistling to the air; which, but for vacancy,
Had gone to gaze on Cleopatra too,
And made a gap in nature.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: Rare Egyptian!

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Upon her landing, Antony sent to her,
Invited her to supper: she replied,
It should be better he became her guest;
Which she entreated: our courteous Antony,
Whom ne'er the word of 'No' woman heard speak,
Being barber'd ten times o'er, goes to the feast,
And for his ordinary pays his heart
For what his eyes eat only.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p:
Royal wench!
She made great Cæsar lay his sword to bed:
He plough'd her, and she cropp'd.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
I saw her once
Hop forty paces through the public street;
And having lost her breath, she spoke, and panted,
That she did make defect perfection,
And, breathless, power breathe forth.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p: Now Antony must leave her utterly.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Never; he will not:
Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale
Her infinite variety: other women cloy
The appetites they feed: but she makes hungry
Where most she satisfies; for vilest things
Become themselves in her: that the holy priests
Bless her when she is riggish.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p:
If beauty, wisdom, modesty, can settle
The heart of Antony, Octavia is
A blessed lottery to him.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p:
Let us go.
Good Enobarbus, make yourself
my guest
Whilst you abide here.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Humbly, sir, I thank you. Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE III
div2.stage: Enter ANTONY, CÆSAR, OCTAVIA between them, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
The world and my great office will
sometimes
Divide me from your bosom.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p:
All which time
Before the gods my knee shall
bow my prayers
To them for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Good night, sir. My Octavia,
Read not my blemishes in the world's report:
I have not kept my square; but that to come
Shall all be done by the rule. Good night, dear lady.
Good night, sir.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Good night. Exeunt Cæsar and Octavia.
Enter Soothsayer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now, sirrah; you do wish yourself in Egypt ?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
Would I had never come from thence, nor you
Thither!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If you can, your reason ?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
I see it in
My motion, have it not in my tongue :
but yet
Hie you to Egypt again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Say to me,
Whose fortunes shall rise higher,
Cæsar's or mine ?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
Cæsar's.
Therefore, O Antony, stay not by his side:
Thy demon, that's thy spirit which keeps thee, is
Noble, courageous, high, unmatchable,
Where Cæsar's is not; but, near him, thy angel
Becomes a fear, as being o'erpower'd: therefore
Make space enough between you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Speak this no more.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
To none but thee; no more, but when to thee.
If thou dost play with him at any game,
Thou art sure to lose; and, of that natural luck,
He beats thee 'gainst the odds: thy lustre thickens,
When he shines by: I say again, thy spirit
Is all afraid to govern thee near him;
But, he away, 'tis noble.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Get thee gone:
Say to Ventidius I would speak with him: Exit Soothsayer.
He shall to Parthia. Be it art or hap,
He hath spoken true : the very dice obey him;
And in our sports my better cunning faints
Under his chance : if we draw lots, he speeds;
His cocks do win the battle still of mine,
When it is all to nought; and his quails ever
Beat mine, inhoop'd, at odds. I will to Egypt:
And though I make this marriage for my peace,
I' the east my pleasure lies. Enter VENTIDIUS.
O, come, Ventidius,
You must to Parthia: your commission's ready;
Follow me, and receive't.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Trouble yourselves no further: pray you,
hasten
Your generals after.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p:
Sir, Mark Antony
Will e'en but kiss Octavia,
and we'll follow.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Till I shall see you in your soldier's dress,
Which will become you both, farewell.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p:
We shall,
As I conceive the journey, be at the
Mount
Before you, Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Your way is shorter;

My purposes do draw me 
much about:

You'll win two days upon me.

sp.speaker: Mec., Agr.
sp.p: Sir, good success !

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: Farewell. Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE V
div2.stage: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Give me some music; music, moody food
Of us that trade in love.

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p:
The music, ho !
Enter MARDIAN the Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Let it alone; let's to billiards: come, Charmian.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My arm is sore; best play with Mardian.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
As well a woman with an eunuch play'd
As
with a woman. Come, you'll play with me, sir ?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: As well as I can, madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
And when good will is show'd,
though't come too short,
The actor may plead pardon. I'll none now:
Give me mine angle; we'll to the river: there,
My music playing far off, I will betray
Tawny-finn'd fishes; my bended hook shall pierce
Their slimy jaws; and, as I draw them up,
I'll think them every one an Antony,
And say 'Ah, ha! you're caught.'

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
'Twas merry when
You wager'd on your angling;
when your diver
Did hang a salt-fish on his hook,
which he
With fervency drew up.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
That time,—O times!—
I laugh'd him out of patience; and that night
I laugh'd him into patience; and next morn,
Ere the ninth hour, I drunk him to his bed;
Then put my tires and mantles on him, whilst
I wore his sword Philippan. Enter a Messenger.
O, from Italy
Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears,
That long time have been barren.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Madam, madam,—

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Antonius dead !—
If thou say so, villain,
Thou kill'st thy mistress:
but well and free,
If thou so yield him,
there is gold, and here
My bluest veins to kiss; a hand that kings
Have lipp'd, and trembled kissing.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: First, madam, he is well.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Why, there's more gold.
But, sirrah, mark, we use
To say the dead are well: bring it to that,
The gold I give thee will I melt and pour
Down thy ill-uttering throat.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Good madam, hear me.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Well, go to, I will;
But there's no goodness in thy face: if Antony
Be free and healthful,—so tart a favor
To trumpet such good tidings! If not well,
Thou shouldst come like a Fury crown'd with snakes,
Not like a formal man.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Will't please you hear me ?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak'st:
Yet, if thou say Antony lives, is well,
Or friends with Cæsar, or not captive to him,
I'll set thee in a shower of gold, and hail
Rich pearls upon thee.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Madam, he's well.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: And friends with Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Thou'rt an honest man.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Cæsar and he are greater friends than ever.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Make thee a fortune from me.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: But yet, madam—

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
I do not like 'But yet,' it does allay
The good precedence; fie upon 'But yet'!
'But yet' is as a gaoler to bring forth
Some monstrous malefactor. Prithee, friend,
Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear,
The good and bad together: he's friends with Cæsar:
In state of health thou say'st; and thou say'st free.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Free, madam! no; I made no such report:
He's bound unto Octavia.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: For what good turn?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: For the best turn i' the bed.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: I am pale, Charmian.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Madam, he's married to Octavia.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
The most infectious pestilence upon thee!
Strikes him down.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Good madam, patience.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
What say you ?
Hence, Strikes him again.
Horrible villain! or I'll spurn thine eyes
Like balls before me; I'll unhair thy head:
She hales him up and down.
Thou shalt be whipp'd with wire, and stew'd in brine,
Smarting in lingering pickle.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Gracious madam,
I that do bring the news made not the match.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Say 'tis not so, a province I will give thee,
And make thy fortunes proud: the blow thou hadst
Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage;
And I will boot thee with what gift beside
Thy modesty can beg.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: He's married, madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Rogue, thou hast lived too long. Draws a knife.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Nay, then I'll run.
What mean you, madam? I have made no fault. Exit.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Good madam, keep yourself within yourself :
The man is innocent.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Some innocents 'scape not the thunderbolt.
Melt Egypt into Nile! and kindly creatures
Turn all to serpents! Call the slave again:
Though I am mad, I will not bite him: call.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He is afeard to come.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
I will not hurt him. Exit Charmian.
These hands do lack nobility, that they strike
A meaner than myself; since I myself
Have given myself the cause.
Re-enter CHARMIAN and Messenger. Come hither, sir.
Though it be honest, it is never good
To bring bad news: give to a gracious message.
An host of tongues; but let ill tidings tell
Themselves when they be felt.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: I have done my duty.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Is he married ?
I cannot hate thee worser than I do,
If thou again say 'Yes.'

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: He's married, madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
The gods confound thee!
dost thou hold there still ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Should I lie, madam?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
O, I would thou didst,
So half my Egypt were submerged and made
A cistern for scaled snakes! Go, get thee hence:
Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face, to me
Thou wouldst appear most ugly. He is married ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
I crave your highness' pardon.
n=98

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: He is married ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Take no offence that I would not offend you:
To punish me for what you make me do.
Seems much unequal: he's married to Octavia.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
O, that his fault should make a knave of thee,
That art not what thou'rt sure of! Get thee hence:
The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome
Are all too dear for me: lie they upon thy hand,
And be undone by 'em! Exit Messenger.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Good your highness, patience.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: In praising Antony, I have dispraised Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Many times, madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
I am paid for't now.
Lead me from hence:
I faint: O Iras, Charmian ! 'tis no matter.
Go to the fellow, good Alexas; bid him
Report the feature of Octavia, her years,
Her inclination, let him not leave out
The color of her hair: bring me word quickly. Exit Alexas.
Let him for ever go :—let him not—Charmian,
Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon,
The other way's a Mars. Bid you Alexas To Mardian.
Bring me word how tall she is. Pity me, Charmian,
But do not speak to me. Lead me to my chamber.
Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE VI
div2.stage:
Flourish. Enter POMPEY and MENAS at one door, with drum and trumpet:
at another, CÆSAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, ENOBARBUS, MECÆNAS,
with Soldiers marching.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Your hostages I have, so have you mine;
And we shall talk before we fight.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Most meet
That first we come to words;
and therefore have we
Our written purposes before us sent;
Which, if thou hast consider'd, let us know
If 'twill tie up thy discontented sword,
And carry back to Sicily much tall youth
That else must perish here.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
To you all three,
The senators alone of this great world,
Chief factors for the gods, I do not know
Wherefore my father should revengers want,
Having a son and friends; since Julius Cæsar,
Who at Philippi the good Brutus ghosted,
There saw you laboring for him. What was't
That moved pale Cassius to conspire; and what
Made the all-honor'd, honest Roman, Brutus,
With the arm'd rest, courtiers and beauteous freedom,
To drench the Capitol; but that they would
Have one man but a man ? And that is it
Hath made me rig my navy; at whose burthen
The anger'd ocean foams; with which I meant
To scourge the ingratitude that despiteful Rome
Cast on my noble father.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: Take your time.

sp.speaker: Ant.
Pom.
sp.p:
At land, indeed,
Thou dost o'er-count me of my father's house :
But, since the cuckoo builds not for himself,
Remain in't as thou mayst.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Be pleased to tell us—
For this is from the present—how you take
The offers we have sent you.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: There's the point.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Which do not be entreated to,
but weigh
What it is worth embraced.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
And what may follow,
To try a larger fortune.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
You have made me offer
Of Sicily, Sardinia; and I must
Rid all the sea of pirates; then, to send
Measures of wheat to Rome; this 'greed upon
To part with unhack'd edges, and bear back
Our targes undinted.

sp.speaker: Cæs. Ant. Lep.
sp.p: That's our offer.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Know, then,
I came before you here
a man prepared
To take this offer: but Mark Antony
Put me to some impatience: though I lose
The praise of it by telling, you must know,
When Cæsar and your brother were at blows,
Your mother came to Sicily and did find
Her welcome friendly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
Pom.
sp.p:
Let me have your hand:
I did not think, sir, to have met you here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
Cæs.
sp.p:
Since I saw you last,
There is a change upon you.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Well, I know not
What counts harsh fortune casts upon my face;
But in my bosom shall she never come,
To make my heart her vassal.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: Well met here.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
I hope so, Lepidus. Thus we are agreed:
I crave our composition may be written,
And seal'd between us.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: That's the next to do.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
We'll feast each other ere we part; and let's
Draw lots who shall begin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That will I, Pompey.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
No, Antony, take the lot: but, first
Or last,
your fine Egyptian cookery
Shall have the fame. I have
heard that Julius Cæsar
Grew fat with feasting there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You have heard much.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: I have fair meanings, sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And fair words to them.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Then so much have I heard:
And I have heard, Apollodorus carried-

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: No more of that: he did so.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: What, I pray you ?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: A certain queen to Cæsar in a mattress.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: I know thee now: how farest thou, soldier ?

sp.speaker: Eno.
Pom.
Eno.
sp.p:
Sir,
I never loved you much; but I ha' praised ye,
When you have well deserved ten times as much
As I have said you did.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Enjoy thy plainness,
It nothing ill becomes thee.
Aboard my galley I invite you all:
Will you lead, lords ?

sp.speaker: Cæs. Ant. Lep.
sp.p: Show us the way, sir.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Come. Exeunt all but Menas and Enobarbus.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Thy father, Pompey, would
ne'er have made this
treaty.—You and I have known, sir.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: At sea, I think.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: We have, sir.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: You have done well by water.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: And you by land.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
I will praise any man that will praise
me; though
it cannot be denied what I have
done by land.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Nor what I have done by water.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Yes, something you can deny for
your own
safety: you have been a great thief by sea.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: And you by land.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
There I deny my land service. But
give me
your hand, Menas: if our eyes had
authority, here they
might take two thieves
kissing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
All men's faces are true, what-
some'er their hands
are.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
But there is never a fair woman has
a true
face.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No slander; they steal hearts.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: We came hither to fight with you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
For my part, I am sorry it is turned
to a drinking.
Pompey doth this day laugh
away his fortune.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: If he do, sure, he cannot weep't back again.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
You've said, sir. We looked not for
Mark Antony
here: pray you, is he married
to Cleopatra?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Cæsar's sister is called Octavia.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
True, sir; she was the wife of Caius
Marcellus.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
But she is now the wife of Marcus
Antonius.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray ye, sir?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Then is Cæsar and he for ever knit
together.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
If I were bound to divine of this
unity, I would
not prophesy so.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
I think the policy of that purpose
made more
in the marriage than the love of
the parties.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
I think so too. But you shall find, the
band
that seems to tie their friendship together
will be the
very strangler of their
amity: Octavia is of a holy, cold,
and still
conversation.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Who would not have his wife so ?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Not he that himself is not so; which
is Mark
Antony. He will to his Egyptian dish
again: then shall
the sighs of Octavia blow
the fire up in Cæsar; and, as I
said before,
that which is the strength of their amity
shall
prove the immediate author of their variance.
Antony
will use his affection where it is: he
married but
his occasion here.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
And thus it may be. Come, sir, will
you aboard ?
I have a health for you.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
I shall take it, sir: we have used our
throats in
Egypt.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Come, let's away. Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE VII
div2.stage: On board Pompey's galley, off Misenum.
Enter two or three Servants with a banquet.

sp.speaker: First Serv.
sp.p:
Here they'll be, man. Some o'
their plants are ill-rooted
already; the least
wind i' the world will blow them
down.

sp.speaker: Sec. Serv.
sp.p: Lepidus is high-colored.

sp.speaker: First Serv.
sp.p:
They have made him drink
alms-drink.

sp.speaker: Sec. Serv.
sp.p:
As they pinch one another by
the disposition, he
cries out 'No more;' reconciles
them to his entreaty, and
himself to
the drink.

sp.speaker: First Serv.
sp.p:
But it raises the greater war
between him and his
discretion.

sp.speaker: Sec. Serv.
sp.p:
Why, this is to have a name in
great men's fellowship:
I had as lief have a
reed that will do me no
service as a partisan
I could not heave.

sp.speaker: First Serv.
sp.p:
To be called into a huge sphere,
and not to be seen
to move in't, are the holes
where eyes should be, which
pitifully disaster the cheeks.
A sennet sounded. Enter CÆSAR, ANTONY,LEPIDUS, POMPEY, AGRIPPA, MECÆNAS,
ENOBARBUS, MENAS, with other captains.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o' the Nile
By certain scales i' the pyramid; they know,
By the height, the lowness, or the mean, if dearth
Or foison follow: the higher Nilus swells,
The more it promises: as it ebbs, the seedsman
Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain,
And shortly comes to harvest.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: You've strange serpents there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ay, Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Your serpent of Egypt is bred now
of your mud
by the operation of your sun: so
is your crocodile.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They are so.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Sit,—and some wine! A health to
Lepidus!

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
I am not so well as I should be,
but
I'll ne'er out.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Not till you have slept; I fear me
you'll be in
till then.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Nay, certainly, I have heard the Ptolemies'
pyramises
are very goodly things; without
contradiction, I
have heard that.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pompey, a word.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Say in mine ear: what is't ?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Forsake thy seat, I do beseech thee, captain,
And hear me speak a word.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Forbear me till anon.
This wine for Lepidus!

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: What manner o' thing is your crocodile ?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
It is shaped, sir, like itself; and it is
as broad as it
hath breadth: it is just so high
as it is, and moves with its
own organs: it
lives by that which nourisheth it; and
the elements
once out of it, it transmigrates.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: What color is it of?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Of it own color too.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange serpent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis so. And the tears of it are wet.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: Will this description satisfy him ?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
With the health that Pompey gives
him, else he
is a very epicure.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Go hang, sir, hang! Tell me of that? away!
Do as I bid you. Where's this cup I call'd for ?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
If for the sake of merit thou wilt hear me,
Rise from thy stool.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: I think thou'rt mad. The matter ? Rises, and walks aside.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Thou hast served me with much faith. What's
else to say ?
Be jolly, lords.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
These quick-sands, Lepidus,
Keep off them, for you sink.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Wilt thou be lord of all the world ?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: What say'st thou ?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Wilt thou be lord of the whole world ?
That's twice.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: How should that be ?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
But entertain it,
And, though thou think me
poor, I am the man
Will give thee all the world.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Hast thou drunk well?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Now, Pompey, I have kept me from the cup.
Thou art, if thou darest be, the earthly Jove:
Whate'er the ocean pales, or sky inclips,
Is thine, if thou wilt ha't.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Show me which way.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
These three world-sharers, these competitors,
Are in thy vessel: let me cut the cable;
And, when we are put off, fall to their throats:
All there is thine.

sp.speaker: Pom.
Men.
sp.p:
For this,
I'll never follow thy pall'd fortunes more.
Who seeks, and will not take when once 'tis offer'd,
Shall never find it more.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: This health to Lepidus!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Bear him ashore.
I'll pledge it for him, Pompey.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Here's to thee, Menas!

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Enobarbus, welcome!

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Fill till the cup be hid.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: There's a strong fellow, Menas. Pointing to the Attendant who carries off Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
A' bears the third part of the world,
man; see'st
not?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
The third part, then, is drunk: would it were
all,
That it might go on wheels!

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Drink thou; increase the reels.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
It ripens towards it. Strike the vessels, ho ?
Here is to Cæsar!

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
I could well forbear 't.
It's monstrous labor,
when I wash my brain,
And it grows fouler.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be a child o' the time.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Possess it, I'll make answer:
But I had rather
fast from all four days
Than drink so much in one.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Ha, my brave emperor! To Antony.
Shall we dance now
the Egyptian Bacchanals,
And celebrate our drink ?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Let's ha't, good soldier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Come, let's all take hands,
Till that the conquering wine hath steep'd our sense
In soft and delicate Lethe.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
All take hands.
Make battery to our ears with the loud music:
The while I'll place you: then the boy shall sing;
The holding every man shall bear as loud
As his strong sides can volley.
Music plays. Enobarbus places them hand in hand.
THE SONG.
Come, thou monarch of the vine,
Plumpy Bacchus with pink eyne!
In thy fats our cares be drown'd,
With thy grapes our hairs be crown'd:
Cup us, till the world go round,
Cup us, till the world go round!

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
What would you more?
Pompey, good night. Good brother,
Let me request you off: our graver business
Frowns at this levity. Gentle lords, let's part;
You see we have burnt our cheeks: strong Enobarb
Is weaker than the wine; and mine own tongue
Splits what it speaks: the wild disguise hath almost
Antick'd us all. What needs more words ? Good night.
Good Antony, your hand.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: I'll try you on the shore.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And shall, sir; give's your hand.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
O Antony,
You have my father's house,--
But, what ? we are friends.
Come, down into the boat.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Take heed you fall not. Exeunt all but Enobarbus and Menas.
Menas, I'll not on shore.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
No, to my cabin.
These drums!
these trumpets, flutes! what!
Let Neptune hear we bid a loud farewell
To these great fellows: sound and be hang'd, sound out!
Sound a flourish, with drums.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Ho ! says a'. There's my cap.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Ho! Noble captain, come. Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage:
Enter VENTIDIUS as it were in triumph, with SILIUS, and other Romans, Officers, and Soldiers; the dead body of PACORUS
borne before him.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p:
Now, darting Parthia, art thou struck; and now
Pleased fortune does of Marcus Crassus' death
Make me revenger. Bear the king's son's body
Before our army. Thy Pacorus, Orodes,
Pays this for Marcus Crassus.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
Noble Ventidius,
Whilst yet with Parthian blood thy sword is warm,
The fugitive Parthians follow; spur through Media,
Mesopotamia, and the shelters whither
The routed fly: so thy grand captain Antony
Shall set thee on triumphant chariots and
Put garlands on thy head.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p:
O Silius, Silius,
I have done enough; a lower place, note well,
May make too great an act: for learn this, Silius;
Better to leave undone, than by our deed
Acquire too high a fame when him we serve's away.
Cæsar and Antony have ever won
More in their officer than person: Sossius,
One of my place in Syria, his lieutenant,
For quick accumulation of renown,
Which he achieved by the minute, lost his favor.
Who does i' the wars more than his captain can
Becomes his captain's captain: and ambition,
The soldier's virtue, rather makes choice of loss,
Than gain which darkens him.
I could do more to do Antonius good,
But 'twould offend him; and in his offence
Should my performance perish.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
Thou hast, Ventidius, that
Without the which a soldier, and his sword,
Grants scarce distinction. Thou wilt write to Antony !

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p:
I'll humbly signify what in his name,
That magical word of war, we have effected;
How, with his banners and his well-paid ranks,
The ne'er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia
We have jaded out o' the field.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Where is he now ?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p:
He purposeth to Athens: whither, with what haste
The weight we must convey with 's will permit,
We shall appear before him. On there; pass along!
Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE II
div2.stage: Rome. An ante-chamber in Cæsar's house.
Enter AGRIPPA at one door, ENOBARBUS at another.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: What, are the brothers parted ?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
They have dispatch'd with Pompey, he is gone;
The other three are sealing. Octavia weeps
To part from Rome; Cæsar is sad; and Lepidus,
Since Pompey's feast, as Menas says, is troubled
With the green sickness.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: 'Tis a noble Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: A very fine one: O, how he loves Cæsar !

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony !

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Cæsar? Why, he's the Jupiter of men.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: What's Antony ? The god of Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Spake you of Cæsar ? How! the nonpareil !

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: O Antony ! O thou Arabian bird !

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Would you praise Cæsar, say 'Cæsar: ' go no further.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
But he loves Cæsar best; yet he loves Antony:
Ho! hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot
Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number, ho!
His love to Antony. But as for Cæsar,
Kneel down, kneel down, and wonder.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: Both he loves.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
They are his shards, and he their beetle. Trumpets within So;
This is to horse. Adieu, noble Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p:
Good fortune, worthy soldier; and farewell.
Enter CÆSAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, and OCTAVIA.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No further, sir.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
You take from me a great part of myself;
Use me well in 't. Sister, prove such a wife
As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest band
Shall pass on thy approof. Most noble Antony,
Let not the piece of virtue, which is set
Betwixt us as the cement of our love,
To keep it builded, be the ram to batter
The fortress of it; for better might we
Have loved without this mean, if on both parts
This be not cherish'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Make me not offended
In your distrust.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: I have said.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
You shall not find,
Though you be therein curious, the least cause
For what you seem to fear: so, the gods keep you,
And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends !
We will here part.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well:
The elements be kind to thee, and make
Thy spirits all of comfort! fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: My noble brother !

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
The April 's in her eyes: it is love's spring,
And these the showers to bring it on. Be cheerful.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Sir, look well to my husband's house; and-

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
What,
Octavia ?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I'll tell you in your ear.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can
Her heart inform her tongue,-the swan's down-feather,
That stands upon the swell at full of tide,
And neither way inclines.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Will Cæsar weep ?

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: He has a cloud in 's face.

sp.speaker: Eno.
Agr.
sp.p:
Why, Enobarbus,
When Antony found Julius Cæsar dead,
He cried almost to roaring; and he wept
When at Philippi he found Brutus slain.

sp.speaker: Eno.
Cæs.
sp.p:
No, sweet Octavia,
You shall hear from me still; the time shall not
Out-go my thinking on you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Come, sir, come;
I'll wrestle with you in my strength of love :
Look, here I have you; thus I let you go,
And give you to the gods.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: Adieu; be happy!

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Let all the number of the stars give light
To thy fair way!

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: Farewell, farewell! Kisses Octavia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Farewell!

div2.head: SCENE III
div2.stage: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Where is the fellow ?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Half afeard to come.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Go to, go to. Enter the Messenger as before.
Come hither, sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Good majesty,
Herod of Jewry dare not look
upon you
But when you are well pleased.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
That Herod's head
I'll have: but how, when
Antony is gone
Through whom I might command it ?
Come thou near.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Most gracious majesty,—

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Didst thou behold Octavia ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Ay, dread queen.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Madam, in Rome;

I look'd her in the face, and 
saw her led

Between her brother and Mark Antony.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Is she as tall as me ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: She is not, madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Didst hear her speak ?
is she shrilltongued or low ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Madam, I heard her speak; she is low-voiced.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: That's not so good: he cannot like her long.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Like her! O Isis! 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
I think so, Charmian: dull of tongue, and dwarfish!
What majesty is in her gait? Remember,
If e'er thou look'dst on majesty.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
She creeps:
Her motion and her station are as one;
She shows a body rather than a life,
A statue than a breather.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Is this certain ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Or I have no observance.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Three in Egypt
Cannot make better note.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
He's very knowing;

I do perceive 't: 
there's nothing in her yet:


The fellow has good judgment.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Guess at her years, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Madam,
She was a widow,—

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Widow! Charmian, hark.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: And I do think she's thirty.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Bear'st thou her face in mind ? is't long or round ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Round even to faultiness.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
For the most part, too, they are foolish that are
so.
Her hair, what color ?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Brown, madam: and her forehead
As low as she would wish it.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
There's gold for thee.
Thou must not take my former sharpness ill:
I will employ thee back again; I find thee
Most fit for business: go make thee ready;
Our letters are prepared. Exit Messenger.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: A proper man.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Indeed, he is so: I repent me much
That so I harried him. Why, methinks, by him,
This creature's no such thing.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Nothing, madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
The man hath seen some majesty, and should
know.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Hath he seen majesty ? Isis else defend,
And
serving you so long!

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
I have one thing more to ask him yet, good
Charmian:
But 'tis no matter; thou shalt bring him to me
Where I will write. All may be well enough.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I warrant you, madam. Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE IV
div2.stage: Athens. A room in Antony's house.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, Octavia, not only that,—
That were excusable, that, and thousands more
Of semblable import,—but he hath waged
New wars 'gainst Pompey; made his will, and read it
To public ear:
Spoke scantly of me:
when perforce he could not
But pay me terms of honor, cold and sickly
He vented them; most narrow measure lent me:
When the best hint was given him, he not took 't,
Or did it from his teeth.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p:
O my good lord,
Believe not all; or, if you must believe,
Stomach not all. A more unhappy lady,
If this division chance, ne'er stood between,
Praying for both parts:
The good gods will mock me presently,
When I shall pray, 'O, bless my lord and husband !'
Undo that prayer, by crying out as loud,
'O, bless my brother!' Husband win, win brother,
Prays, and destroys the prayer; no midway
'Twixt these extremes at all.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Gentle Octavia,
Let your best love draw to that point, which seeks
Best to preserve it: if I lose mine honor,
I lose myself: better I were not yours
Than yours so branchless. But, as you requested,
Yourself shall go between 's: the mean time, lady,
I'll raise the preparation of a war
Shall stain your brother: make your soonest haste;
So your desires are yours.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p:
Thanks to my lord.
The Jove of power make me most weak, most weak,
Your reconciler ! Wars 'twixt you twain would be
As if the world should cleave, and that slain men
Should solder up the rift.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
When it appears to you where this begins,
Turn your displeasure that way; for our faults
Can never be so equal, that your love
Can equally move with them. Provide your going;
Choose your own company, and command what cost
Your heart has mind to. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: How now, friend Eros!

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.p: There's strange news come, sir.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: What, man ?

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.p:
Cæsar and Lepidus have made wars
upon Pompey.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: This is old: what is the success ?

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.p:
Cæsar, having made use of him in
the wars
'gainst Pompey, presently denied him
rivality; would not
let him partake in the
glory of the action: and not resting
here, accuses
him of letters he had formerly wrote to
Pompey; upon his own appeal, seizes him: so
the poor
third is up, till death enlarge his confine.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Then, world, thou hast a pair of chaps, no more;


And throw between them all the food thou hast,

They'll 
grind the one the other. Where's Antony ?

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.p:
He's walking in the garden—thus; and spurns
The rush that lies before him; cries, 'Fool Lepidus!'
And threats the throat of that his officer
That murder'd Pompey.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Our great navy's rigg'd.

sp.speaker: Eros.
Eno.
sp.p:
'Twill be naught:
But let it be. Bring me to Antony.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Contemning Rome, he has done all this, and more,
In Alexandria: here's the manner of 't:
I' the market-place, on a tribunal silver'd,
Cleopatra and himself in chairs of gold
Were publicly enthroned: at the feet sat
Cæsarion, whom they call my father's son,
And all the unlawful issue that their lust
Since then hath made between them. Unto her
He gave the stablishment of Egypt; made her
Of lower Syria, Cyprus, Lydia,
Absolute queen.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p: This in the public eye ?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
I' the common show-place, where they exercise.
His sons he there proclaim'd the kings of kings:
Great Media, Parthia, and Armenia,
He gave to Alexander; to Ptolemy he assign'd
Syria, Cilicia, and Phoenicia: she
In the habiliments of the goddess Isis
That day appear'd; and oft before gave audience,
As 'tis reported, so.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p:
Let Rome be thus
Inform'd.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p:
Who, queasy with his insolence
Already,
will their good thoughts call from him.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
Agr.
sp.p: Who does he accuse ?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Cæsar: and that, having in Sicily
Sextus Pompeius spoil'd, we had not rated him
His part o' the isle: then does he say, he lent me
Some shipping unrestored: lastly, he frets
That Lepidus of the triumvirate
Should be deposed;
and, being, that we detain
All his revenue.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: Sir, this should be answer'd.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
'Tis done already, and the messenger gone.
I have told him, Lepidus was grown too cruel;
That he his high authority abused,
And did deserve his change: for what I have conquer'd,
I grant him part; but then, in his Armenia,
And other of his conquer'd kingdoms, I
Demand the like.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p: He'll never yield to that.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Nor must not then be yielded to in this.
Enter OCTAVIA with her train.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Hail, Cæsar, and my lord ! hail, most dear Cæsar!

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: That ever I should call thee castaway !

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You have not call'd me so, nor have you cause.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p:
Why have you stol'n upon us thus! You come not
Like Cæsar's sister: the wife of Antony
Should have an army for an usher, and
The neighs of horse to tell of her approach
Long ere she did appear; the trees by the way
Should have borne men; and expectation fainted,
Longing for what it had not; nay, the dust
